instruction: What kinds of spectrum was used in the monitoring model of the biochemical components of tea leaves?
Output: The monitoring model of the biochemical components of tea leaves used spectral data obtained during the withering and fermentation of the raw materials.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used in the monitoring model of the biochemical components of tea leaves?
Output: The spectral feature processing methods used in the monitoring model of the biochemical components of tea leaves were Savitzky–Golay (S-G), multiple scatter correction (MSC), and first derivative (1D) algorithms.

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the performance of the monitoring model and how far can this metric go in the monitoring model of the biochemical components of tea leaves?
Output:
The metric chosen to evaluate the performance of the monitoring model is the coefficient of determination (R-squared). The R-squared value measures the proportion of the variance in the dependent variable (biochemical components of tea leaves) that can be explained by the independent variables (spectral data and machine learning models). 

The text states that the coefficient of determination for the prediction set is 0.91 for tea polyphenols (TPs), 0.88 for free amino acids (FAA), and 0.81 for caffeine (CAF). This indicates that the monitoring model can explain 91%, 88%, and 81% of the variance in the TPs, FAA, and CAF contents, respectively. 

Therefore, the chosen metric of coefficient of determination provides a measure of how well the monitoring model can predict and explain the variations in the biochemical components of tea leaves.

instruction: What machine learning models were used to establish the monitoring model for the biochemical components of tea leaves based on hyperspectral imaging technology?
Output: The machine learning models used to establish the monitoring model for the biochemical components of tea leaves based on hyperspectral imaging technology are support vector machine (SVM), random forest (RF), and partial least square (PLS).

instruction: Can hyperspectral imaging technology be used to establish a monitoring model for quantitatively judging the withering and fermentation degrees of fresh tea leaves?
Output: Yes, hyperspectral imaging technology can be used to establish a monitoring model for quantitatively judging the withering and fermentation degrees of fresh tea leaves. The text states that a monitoring model of the biochemical components of tea leaves based on hyperspectral imaging technology was established to quantitatively judge the withering and fermentation degrees of fresh tea leaves. Hyperspectral imaging technology was used to obtain the spectral data during the withering and fermentation of the raw materials. This model, combined with feature band selection methods and machine learning models, was able to accurately predict the content of tea polyphenols, free amino acids, and caffeine, as well as quantitatively judge the withering and fermentation degrees.
